fields.Title of Contribution: Interaction between temperature and substrate moisture onsurvivability of a substrate burrowing, air-breathing, non-nativefish, oriental weatherfish, (Misgurnus anguillicaudatus), in Idaho,USA
fields.Journal: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society
fields.Description/Abstract: Objective: Establishment and spread of invasive species depend on how well the species<br>acclimates and adapts to new local conditions. We subjected adult oriental weatherfish Misgurnus anguillicaudatus (n = 47) to four treatment combinations of two temperatures (30 0 C and 40 0 C) and two substrate moisture levels (&lt; 20% VMC and ≥ 50% VMC) in a regulated temperature and moisture control chamber in the laboratory to test survivability under these conditions. At the high substrate moisture level (≥ 50% volumetric moisture content (VMC)) and warm temperature (30 0 C), oriental weatherfish survived up to 184 days. In both high substrate moisture (≥ 50% VMC) and dry substrate (&lt; 20% VMC), at hot temperature (40 0 C), the fish did not survive for more than a few days. At 30 0 C and dry substrate (&lt; 20% VMC), oriental weatherfish survived up to 25 days. Our results indicate a tolerance of 30 0 C and substrate moisture ≥ 50% VMC, is a strong indicator of range expansion ability and invasive risk by the burrowing, air-breathing fish, oriental weatherfish. This knowledge can be used by managers to better predict range expansions under a changing climate.
